scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Record Group 3 documents the work of the Foundation's officers through their correspondence and subject files, speeches and writings. It contains files for presidents Creed Black, C.C. Gibson, Ben Maidenburg and Hodding Carter; treasurers Charles Clark and DavidCatrow; chief program officers James Spaniolo and Penelope McPhee; chief financial officer Timothy Crowe; and co-founders John and James Knight. The papers of Chairman of the Board Lee Hills are particularly important to this record group. They contain a complete record of the Foundation's activities and issues during the years 1968 to the early 1990s. Most Foundation records dating before the move to Miami in 1990 exist only on microfiche, or in Lee Hills' papers.

userestrict.head: Conditions Governing Use
userestrict.p: Knight Foundation has title, copyright and literary rights in the collection, in so far as it holds them.

The Rockefeller Archive Center has authority to grant permission to cite and publish material from the collection. Permission to publish extensive excerpts, or material in its entirety, will be referred to the Knight Foundation.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Creed C. Black, President, 1987-1998. Mr. Black's papers are contained in six letter size boxes. One box of files records the National Community Development Initiative, Strategic Planning, the Cities Program, and the Symphony Initiative. There are also files on legal issues, including a memo and reference materials from Lee Hills to the Trustees in 1982 on Conflicts of Interest; guidance for Trustees and Advisors on distributing grants (1988); and correspondence on the relationship between Knight Foundation and Knight-Ridder (1991). One box refers to the relocation of Knight Foundation offices from Akron to Miami. Mr. Black's correspondence can also be found in the files on the Knight Commission for Intercollegiate Athletics (SEE Record Group 6), the National Community Development Initiative and the Cities Program (SEE Record Group 5, Community Initiatives), the Journalism Program (SEE Record Group 5, Journalism), and in Board of Trustees files (SEE Record Group 1, Board of Trustees).

scopecontent.p: Lee Hills, Trustee 1960-2000. His files are housed in fifteen letter size boxes and are arranged alphabetically by subject. The Knight Foundation Archives obtained copies of selected papers concerning the Foundation from Mr. Hills in 1996 when the Archives was created. After arranging and copying the papers, Mr. Hills's original papers were returned to him. These papers consist of Mr. Hill's notes, memos and correspondence created during his career as Knight Foundation's Vice-Chairman from 1960-1990, and Chairman from 1991 to 1995. The materials contained in the files document the creation and evolution of several key areas of the Foundation's operations, including Strategic Planning, the Cities Program (later called Community Initiatives) and its Advisors, the Journalism Program, as well as various advisory committees, policies, and grant making decisions.
Three boxes contain grant write-ups for trustees meetings held between 1971 and 1986, a period for which there are no Board Books (where the write-ups are usually found).

Lee Hills' notes taken at trustees meetings (filed under "TrusteesMeetings") contain information about planning for the future of the Foundation after John S. Knight's death in 1981. There are files on comparison visits to other foundations between 1981 and 1983 (filed under "Foundation Visits," and "Gannett Foundation"). Background information on the re-incorporation of Knight Foundation in Florida in 1993, the selection of future board members, and the deliberations over grant decisions are also included in the files.

There are abundant materials regarding planning for the Foundation, particularly after the death of James L. Knight in 1991. Documents pertaining to planning can be found under "Consultants - Arthur Raybin Associates," "Committees - Planning and Program," and "Committees - Planning." These papers date between 1991 and 1992, when Nancy Raybin was hired as a consultant to plan for Knight Foundation's financial growth upon receiving the bulk of James Knight's estate in 1991.

The infancy of the Community Initiatives Program is visible in documents dating back to 1974, under "Community Advisors," where correspondence concerns the issue of having local Knight-Ridder editors advise the Foundation regarding grant requests in their area. Later correspondence documents the expansion of communities served by the Cities Program, guidelines for the Program in 1988, and the evolution into the Community Initiatives Program in 1991. Also SEE Mr. Hills's Speeches in this Record Group for talks he gave concerning the Cities Program.

Extensive documentation of the Journalism Program can be found in Mr. Hills' files, particularly related to the development of Knight Chairs in Journalism and mid-career journalism fellowships at several prominent universities, including Stanford, the University of Michigan, Massachusetts Institute of Technology, and Northwestern University. The John S. Knight Fellowship Program at Stanford is particularly well documented. The files, dating 1971-1989, chronicle the formation, growth and success of the program.

Finance materials in Mr. Hills' papers give insight into the management of Foundation funds and the legal responsibility of the trustees had in dealing with excess business holdings, and the 1989 bequest from the Dorothy Knight Trust.
